Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 50236-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
May 2017 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic: Preparing the 
Sustainable Rural Infrastructure and Watershed 
Management Sector Project  
Cofinanced by Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and 
Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Public Communications 
Policy 2011. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  Rationale. The core problem of the agriculture, natural resources and rural development 
sector in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) can be summarized as low agricultural 
productivity, quality, diversity, and unrealized trade potential, with a rapidly eroding natural 
resource production base due to physical, economic, and capacity constraints. Climate change 
impacts are exacerbating losses in agriculture investments, increasing the risks of food insecurity, 
poverty, and inequality.  
 
2.  The  proposed  Sustainable  Rural  Infrastructure  and  Watershed  Management  Sector 
Project (the project) will increase the profitability of the agriculture, natural resources and rural 
development sector to be aligned with the following impact: sustainable and inclusive rural 
development achieved.1 Its outcome will be sustainable, market oriented agricultural production 
and natural resources management in selected watersheds enhanced. The project has three 
outputs: (i) productive rural infrastructure (PRI) upgraded to be climate resilient, efficient, and 
sustainable;  (ii)  land  use  management  within  the  PRI  scheme  watersheds  improved;  and 
(iii) institutional  arrangements  and  capacity  for  good  agriculture  practices  and  sustainable 
watershed management improved. 
 
3.  The indicative investment cost of the project is estimated at $56.7 million, including $30.0 
million concessional ordinary capital resources loan, $4.7 million grant from the ADB Disaster 
Risk Reduction Fund, $10.0 million grant from the Green Climate Fund (GCF), $10.0 million loan 
from GCF, and $2.0 million from the government as counterpart funding. Out of this amount, the 
amount of climate change adaptation is estimated to cost $35.0 million. ADB will finance $15.0 
million and GCF will finance $20.0 million. In addition, The Food and Agriculture Organization of 
the United Nations (FAO) parallel cofinancing from GCF estimated at $15.0 million is envisaged.2 
The project is included in the Lao PDR Country Operations Business Plan (2017-2019). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
4.  A transaction technical assistance (TRTA) is needed to help the government to prepare 
the ensuing project. It will define the scope, cost, procedures for identifying subprojects, financing 
plan, implementation arrangements, procurement, technology issues, capacity development, 
maintenance arrangements, and adherence to ADB safeguard policies. It will also provide 
advance action support to enhance project readiness, as well as to ensure that PRI is designed 
in a climate change resilient manner.3 The TRTA draft final reports will include the whole set of 
ADB-required project documents (report and recommendation of the President and its linked 
documents and supplementary documents) and GCF-required documents including the concept 
paper and the full application for both the ADB and FAO GCF proposals.4  
 
                                                
1  This is aligned with the 8th National Economic and Social Development Plan (2016-2020) and the National Strategy 
on Climate Change (2010). 
2  Whereas ADB’s strength lies with the development of infrastructure, partners are needed to realize the full impact of 
the project. The project will enter into a parallel cofinancing with the FAO. They will lead a consortium that will assist 
to  implement  watershed  management,  capacity  development,  rural  credit  schemes,  and  improve  hydro-
meteorological monitoring. The consortium is expected to include: International Water Management Institute, 
International Rice Research Institute, and other organizations and experts.  
3  First appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 May 2017. 
4  See http://www.greenclimate.fund/funding/proposal-approval/fine-print for the GCF approval process.

2 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
5.  Output 1: Sector and institutional analyses will be prepared by the consultants as part 
of the inception report to be produced to identify gaps, issues and opportunities for strengthening 
the institutions to support the project activities. Based on these findings, the report will include 
three main sections corresponding to three outputs of the ensuing project as follows:  
 
(i)  PRI. The TRTA will (a) assess impact of climate variability and climate change and 
associated issues on the selected PRI, and develop measures for increased climate 
resilience for these PRI; (b) assess impact of PRI on aquatic ecosystems and fisheries 
and develop mitigation measures; (c) develop criteria and guidance for the selection of 
PRI schemes; and (d) prepare a list of PRI schemes for which feasibility studies will be 
prepared during the TRTA and during implementation. 
 
(ii)  Land use management in PRI scheme watersheds. The TRTA will (a) develop 
guidelines  for  upstream-downstream  cooperation  in  the  selected  watersheds; 
(b) recommend feasible watershed management measures for the selected subprojects; 
and  (c)  study  political  economy  and  capacities  and  provide  recommendations  for 
watershed planning. 
 
(iii)  Institutional strengthening and capacity building for sustainable watershed 
management. The TRTA will: (a) develop institutional arrangements at the provincial level 
to  ensure  inter-agency  coordination;  (b)  develop  a  hydro-meteorological  monitoring 
framework for application in the subproject watersheds; and (c) prepare a capacity building 
program for good and climate smart agriculture practices and for sustainable watershed 
management.   
 
6.  Output  2: Feasibility  studies  prepared for three  to five  subprojects.  Based  on 
technical and social surveys from output 1, feasibility studies of three to five subprojects that will 
will be prepared. The feasibilities will include climate-resilient preliminary designs, economic and 
financial analysis, and social and environmental safeguards. These feasibility studies will serve 
as the model for studies of further subprojects during project implementation.   
 
7.  Output 3: Detailed engineering designs (DEDs) and bidding documents. The TRTA 
will prepare climate-resilient DEDs and bidding documents for three to five selected subprojects. 
Advance actions will also be undertaken for the procurement of these subprojects.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
8.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $2.04 million equivalent, of which $1.50 million is financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and $0.50 million on a grant 
basis by the Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund5 (PRITF), both administered by ADB. 
The government will finance the remaining balance in-kind. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1.  
 
9.  Under the JFPR, ineligible expenditures include: (i) purchase of vehicles; (ii) salaries for 
civil servants; (iii) any foreign travel; (iv) scholarships or long internships; (v) detailed engineering; 
                                                
5 Financing partner: Nordic Development Fund.

3 
(vi) civil works and other related expenses; and (vii) those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or 
Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities List.6 
 
10.  Under the PRITF, expenditures can support project preparatory-related activities which 
are not covered by the Technical Assistance Special Fund resources and/or by cofinancing from 
external sources or other ADB-administered trust funds. These include: (i) preparation of DEDs; 
(ii) preparation and launch of bidding documents; (iii) guidance on advanced procurement; and 
(iv) additional feasibility studies, not included in the original TRTA scope, related to project 
readiness and addressing climate change, such as but not limited to estimation of costs for 
adaptation, detailed climate risk and vulnerability assessment, developing baseline data. 
 
11.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff, 
secretarial assistance, provision of office space, communication facilities, and other in-kind 
contributions with the value estimated at about 2% of the total technical assistance cost. The 
government was informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB will administer the technical assistance. 
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements

4

Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
13.  Consulting services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The following 
consultants will be engaged:  
 
(i)  A TRTA firm providing 40 person-months (p-m) of international and 70 p-m of 
national consultants will be recruited through quality-and cost-based selection 
method  using  a  quality-cost  ratio  of  90:10  and  a  full  technical  proposal. 
International specialists preferably have a master’s degree, extensive relevant 
experience in their area of expertise, and experience working in Lao PDR; 
national specialists have an undergraduate degree. The team will have an array 
of  expertise  in  natural  resources  management,  water  engineering, 
bioengineering,  fish  passage,  agriculture  development  and  extension, 
agriculture  value  chain  development,  financial  management,  procurement, 
economics,  climate  change,  environmental  and  social  safeguards,  social 
development and gender, and DED.   
 
(ii)  The International Water Management Institute will be recruited through single 
source selection to provide flood and drought risk assessments (8.5 p-m). They 
have  exceptional  experience  worldwide  and  in  particular  in  Lao  PDR  in 
hydrological research and in the assessment of impacts from climate and land 
use change including flood risk assessments which makes it the only entity 
qualified.  
 
(iii)  Individual consultants to provide expertise on project preparation and start-up 
implementation (3 p-m). 
 
14.  The  TRTA  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  the  procurement  of  office  equipment 
(computers, printers, a photocopier, cameras and Global Positioning Systems devices estimated 
at $8,100), organizing all workshops/trainings/conferences, and engagement of survey teams for 
two surveys using shopping method: (i) baseline and socio-economic surveys; and (ii) engineering 
surveys for the selected subprojects, estimated at $170,000 in total.7 
 
15.  Detailed engineering design. DEDs will be prepared for three to five subprojects. They 
will be exclusively funded under the PRITF, in accordance with the Fund’s implementation 
guidelines.8 The executing agency will hold the consultants accountable for any defect liability 
and such arrangements will be reflected in the TRTA letter, and the DED consultants’ terms of 
reference and contract.  
 
                                                
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
8  ADB 2016. Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund Implementation Guidelines.

5 
16.  Cofinancier requirements. Under JFPR, the implementing project officer will furnish 
ADB’s Office of Cofinancing Operations with copy of progress reports, and back-to-office reports 
of all missions (inception, review, mid-term review, and completion). Copy of the completion report 
will also be shared with the Embassy of Japan and the Japan International Cooperation Agency 
office  in  Lao  PDR.  High  resolution  photos  and  testimonials  from  project  recipients  and 
implementers, copies of publications, and sample products generated from the project will also 
be provided to ADB’s Office of Cofinancing Operations as part of project documentation and for 
knowledge dissemination purposes. Under PRITF, the implementing project officer will provide 
input to the annual progress of the fund, including activities supported by the fund, analysis of 
progress made towards expected results, and the work program for the coming year. The report 
will be submitted to the donors of the fund within the first quarter of each new calendar year.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and (ii) ADB administering the technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Project 
Readiness Improvement Trust Fund to the Government of Lao PDR for preparing the Sustainable 
Rural Infrastructure and Watershed Management Sector Project, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
Date
